reviewText:
Telltale follows in the footsteps of HBO's Game of Thrones and the book series that inspired it. Not just in terms of theme and fateful moments, almost a trope of their own at this point, but also by stringing you along for as long as possible seemingly without ever reaching a conclusion. It's no surprise then that Telltale is set to release a second season of its Game of Thrones episodic game.

There is, of course, something to be said for your characters being victims in a world of more powerful and influential figures and authorities. That is fine, up to a point, but it stops being interesting once you reach Idiot Plot levels of restrictions on your actions. As Roger Ebert explained, an Idiot Plot 'is any plot that would be resolved in five minutes if everyone in the story were not an idiot'. Far too often the game offers up dumb choices that are all bad ideas under the circumstances - or leaves out the option of taking the kind of action that would resolve the situation in the character’s favour. Because the game offers no actual gameplay, its dialogue options cannot offer you the means by which to succeed outside of the narrow pre-set path defined by Telltale. Doing so would mean the conflict Telltale has sketched out would never come to pass, and that has to be prevented - even if it means turning your characters into what might well be the least clever House of Westeros. It's often hilarious because the Forresters have mastered the art of failing, but also frustrating and ultimately not very rewarding.

The graphics are limited, but more crucial in a game like this is that the facial expressions Telltale has managed to create lag far behind what LA Noire was able to accomplish years ago, making the conversations that are the game's only meaningful content unconvincing.

Not recommended.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's hard to pick a starting point to list all of this game's problems, but maybe a good start would be Telltale's old, buggy engine being reused. While the studio does have the capacity to produce very fun and interesting games, such as Tales From the Borderlands which was produces around the same time as this one, Game of Thrones might easily be considered Telltales' worst game. It often pulls twists for the sake of shock, the characters aren't likeable or interesting, plot armor runs rather rampant (especially noticeable on the second playthrough) and the story is very unfullfilling. Most of Telltales' games are better when you see them as movies, but this game fails at both departments, I'm afraid.

reviewText:
A great game. At first I couldn't think of anything that would be a good addition to the Game of Thrones series, but in the end I was seriously surprised. The story is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ intense - every decision you make either gets you into some deep ♥♥♥♥ or in even deeper ♥♥♥♥.. If you ask me TTG did another masterpiece, it feels just as punishing and twisting as the series itself. I don't want to tell any more so I can avoid spoiling you guys.

There are only few downsides. Let's start with the smallest. If you are sensible to blood and/or to painful decisions, don't play this. Ripping someone's heart out is just not a thing everyone is cool with.
Also there are minor (!) bugs. For instance characters not being correctly loaded and them readjusting after 1/2s of you seeing them.. Or Eyes doing weird things every now and then. Emphasis on minor because I did not experience a single gamebreaking glitch - not even a single crash. And I'm not even sure whether said bugs only appear due to my weak graphics card. Nevertheless if you buy it, please keep in mind this game (like all TTG story games) focus on the story instead of graphics - some people don't want to buy such games because of the mediocre graphics, although it's one hell of an unique experience .-.


All things considered I think this is a great addition to the GoT series. The price is completely reasonable and it's one of the most unique experiences I ever had in a video game! Definitely recommended <3

reviewText:
A decent game, would give a more neutral recommendation if that were possible.

In the Telltale series, you are thrust into the world of the Forresters, a house greatly shaken after the events of the Red wedding. This house (as far as i know) is not canon, so the series of events within the game are not even legitimate within the world of Ice and Fire.

Positives:
Portrays the affects of the Red Wedding on a minor house, giving a bit more depth to the George R.R. Martin world
Most of the Gameplay is quite simple, though this can also be seen as being negative
Entertaining plot throughout the game

Negatives:
The choices you make are quite limited, and often don't affect the game at all
The writers tried to make a lot of shocking deaths to emulate the TV show, but in my opinion went a bit too verboard and just seemed to want to create as much shock value as possible
A couple of the Charecters you make choices for are extemely annoying, to the point were instead of wanting the character to stay alive, you end up willingly helping them meet their demise (for me this was Ethan)
A lot of the choices you are given are the exact same as their counterparts, just rewritten differently
Not all possible choices are reflected in the dialouge choice list, and I found myself wishing I could have said what I wanted, and that often would have saved lives

All up, this is a good game if you're heavily invested in the ASOIAF lore, but otherwise I'd just give it a miss

reviewText: I've read in a Telltale Games interview that the way they do their games is by having the story first, and then proceeding to the game. This is a nice concept, except that the story is so important that it feels that, as gamers, we're merely expectators in an unfolding tragedy. We can pick some dialogs, and press the occasional up / left / right arrow, but whatever you do, it ultimately does not matter - the choices are limited, and the end is grim no matter what you do. By the way, the combat system is awful, and feels like a second thought thrown in to give the players something to do.\n\nIf, however, you are more interested in some type of visual novel / interactive fiction, then this might be your cup of tea.

reviewText:
Let's keep it short, I wasted enough time on this already playing the whole damn thing.

So again it's striking me as to how long Telltale keeps their engine around while pushing out yet another licensed story from a franchise I care about. The animations are weak and figures pop in and out of scenes so bloody obvious it's getting annoying. Yet, I do like the tone and atmosphere of the game, especially the art style.

The 4 storylines are not in your favor and you can see it. George R. R. Martin hasn't delayed his book for no reason, because it takes time to accomplish something truely unique. This is just a game about NPCs, even if they're a noble family. Nobody cares about NPCs and that's why this game is not a worthy addition to the lore, if it is even considered such.

The only really good thing about this game was we combat scenes with Asher Forrester in the later game. Kept me excited, yet the other parts, the politics, were so boring on the other side that it's just a small patch on the otherwise patchwork.

Please, consider fast forwarding in your future games, even if you don't get to tell the story you intend to deliver. It's sometimes easier, especially when the bloody game crashes after a false save and I have to relive certain scenes over and over again just before I try a rewind on the chapter.

My final statement: if you are really thirsty for Game of Thrones, you'll get your Valar Morghulis. If you are a fan of good storytelling, even from Telltale, you'd be better off without this game.

That is fine, up to a point, but it stops being interesting once you reach Idiot Plot levels of restrictions on your actions. As Roger Ebert explained, an Idiot Plot 'is any plot that would be resolved in five minutes if everyone in the story were not an idiot'. Far too often the game offers up dumb choices that are all bad ideas under the circumstances - or leaves out the option of taking the kind of action that would resolve the situation in the character’s favour. Because the game offers no actual gameplay, its dialogue options cannot offer you the means by which to succeed outside of the narrow pre-set path defined by Telltale. Doing so would mean the conflict Telltale has sketched out would never come to pass, and that has to be prevented - even if it means turning your characters into what might well be the least clever House of Westeros. It's often hilarious because the Forresters have mastered the art of failing, but also frustrating and ultimately not very rewarding.

The graphics are limited, but more crucial in a game like this is that the facial expressions Telltale has managed to create lag far behind what LA Noire was able to accomplish years ago, making the conversations that are the game's only meaningful content unconvincing.

Not recommended.

reviewText:
I had mixed feeling about the game, since I was content with the game until the end of the fourth episode. I would have recommended if I had written a review then. It is a fun game with good premise, faithful to the TV series (and, in some cases, even better).

The reason I write a negative review is that the basic premise of the game has turned out to be false: your choices don't matter at all. The whole plot runs on tracks and if you try to leave the railroad, the universe will stretch and bend in most horrific ways to keep you there. The characters will behave irrationally to force a specific outcome, their accomplishments will get ignored, failures will turn out not to be that bad after all.

Some examples (spoilered):


1. Didn't manage to secure a betrothal which would give you warriors necessary to fight your antagonist? Your beloved will come anyway, stealing twenty elite soldiers from her father like they were robots that can be hacked.
2. Succeeded spectacularly in Essos and got rewarded with a chest of gold? It's only enough to hire less than a dozen barechested former gladiators, half of whom die five minutes after reaching Westeros.
3. Don't want to fight the murderer of your family when on the Wall? He'll attack you himself. It appears that despite everyone being on guard because of Mance Rayder marching on the Castle Black, no one hears two people screaming and hacking each other with swords. Everyone thinks you're guilty, even if it means disbelieving the only witness of the fight that even doesn't like you.

I still want to see how the Season 2 will unfold, but I don't have much hope after what I have seen.

reviewText:
Warning. Spoiler-ish and less of a review, more of a downpour of heart blood.

****

I feel deceived.

It finally dawned on me in the last episode that everything you do in this game always turns to poop. Up to that point, I had the feeling crossed off as Martinesque harshness and kept hoping that eventually one of the characters I'm rooting for is going to pull through and save the family from ruin, but no. Honourable and ruthless, admirable and abominable, all my tough decisions were harshly punished, never rewarded. I went from assured to hopeful to desperate - and when even my hope for vengeange ran away from me and my disbelieving curses through barred gates and guards with an axe in his back and lived, I altogether stopped caring.

In a way, it is refreshing to encounter a story that puts you in your place as a lowly human, not an indomitable hero predestined for a happily-ever-after. Just someone trying to scrape by like the rest. I mean, maybe I deserved this for taking flowery endings for granted.

But it doesn't make for a rewarding experience, when you're told your decisions matter and in reality, you'll be dunked in the dung pile no matter what. It's deppressing really. Yeah... I think I'll go dress-up as Superman or something, just to get over all this.

reviewText:
This is exactly what a story focused game should be like and Telltale have successfully created a gripping story from a TV/ book series again. This time they have created an original story based in George R.R. Martin's hugely successful ASOIAF. Telltale have outdone themselves by recreating how HBO's Game of Thones plays out using actors from the TV series as voice actors helping you to immerse yourself in the world of Westeros. They have created what is basically an interactive episode of Game of Thrones by using the exciting situations you would find in the show. They have done a great job of ending on a high note just as the series always does.

In this game you control different characters from a Northern house, House Forrester. The members of this family are seen in many of Westeros' famous settings allowing you to see everything the world as to offer from Kings Landing to The Wall and Essos. Your rival House, House Whitehill, seeks to claim your family's reknowned resource Ironwood for themselves and you must use anything you have to stop them.

PROS:
-Original story
-Relatable and interesting characters
-Exciting endings
-Great recreations of the World
-Actors from the show
-Exactly like how Game of Thrones would act
-Great Choices

CONS:
-It was hard to find any cons to this game. The only thing I can think of is the background graphics. The charaters looked amazing up close but the background graphics, while not a huge problem to me, were washed out unlike the other Telltale titles.

I highly recommend that anyone who is interested in ASOIAF and Game of Thrones should buy this game. It will not disappoint.

reviewText:
This review used to be longer, but Steam’s limited the number of characters I could type, so I have decided to make a spoiler-free review.

As an overall, I could say this is a decent game. It is mildly fun, and, unlike many Telltale copycats, every episode has always something to fill it up, to make it a concise story that always has something going on for it.

However, this game suffers a lot, and I believe this is something common to the genre (that I find to have an interesting concept, even though being not approachable to me due to all of these limitations nonetheless). The truth is, this is nothing but a linear plot with some dialogue options that bear no major influence to anything in the end; your story is basically the same as the ones other players experience. Apart from some little details that make no considerable changes to the narrative, Game of Thrones is a live-rendered flat story that gives you the possibility of sometimes choosing dialogue and enduring not-at-all creative quick time events.

Below I expand more on some of my thoughts on this game.

Pros:
Beautifully drawn scenery and backgrounds. It reminds me of a more crude version of Pillars of Eternity’s artwork.
Decent voice acting. I still noticed something bad going on on a few voice tracks due to bad recording and bad compression. Anyway, not stellar, but a good job still. Oh, and the music is alright.
Very long episodes (except that last one). I feel satisfied every time I finish a few episodes and find out that it is 5 AM and I should be sleeping because my life starts at 6. If I want to play a story-based game, I don’t want it to only take thirty minutes of my life for every episode. I want it to be filled with a lot of content and stuff happening all the time. This game does this pretty well.
Cons:
Forced plots everywhere. Also, you don’t have the option to do many things only because the game doesn’t want you to.
Almost all characters are extremely boring.
Your choices make no difference. To be short: It doesn’t matter what you choose, the end results in the story are always going to be the same. Few exceptions are made. There are virtually no ramified paths in this story whatsoever.
Many graphical glitches here and there. Unlike most people, I don’t think the character models in this game are hideous. They’re not stunning, but they get the job done. Still, there were even moments where entire character models didn’t load properly.
What is up with their faces? Why can’t Telltale Games stop their characters from grinning, widening and squeezing their eyelids uncontrollably? And I can’t help but notice how the background characters are just standing there, flat-faced while such theaters occur before them. Most of the time even their postures are all the same. Really?

reviewText:
I will start by saying for a fan of Telltale and of Game of Thrones/A Song of Ice and Fire I would suggest checking this out. Overall the experience wasn't on the same level as say Telltale's The Walking Dead Season 1 & 2 but was enjoyable and a good way to spend a few hours every couple of months. Now that the full season has been released I feel obliged to give my experience of the game.

The game started off really strongly, with the first few episodes having me on my toes just waiting for what happened next but the excitement and compassion I felt for the characters in the story slowly declined as the season progressed. The illusion of choice is still present from previous Telltale games, as is the formula, but this time I was really disappointed to see some of the major choices the game presented me with having little to no major effect on the story, especially when it should have been impactful.

This leads me to the ending of the game. Here the endings start to verge off from one another, much like at the ending of Season 2 of The Walking Dead, but the cliffhanger it ends on gives no resolution to the entirety of the game. I view this as a blatent money making opportunity on the behalf of Telltale. I do however understand that they are a company and their goal is to make money but I would be happier to purchase a continuation of this season if they had executed the ending better.

(I'll also mention the length of the wait between episode 5 and 6 was ridiculously long, which helped to lose a great deal of tension in the story. at least for me it did)

Despite the ending and the long wait I will give Telltale credit where credit is due:
- The visuals were fantastically suited to the style of game
- The story, while slow in places, was pretty enjoyable
- The cast of characters, both playable and non playable, really made the game for me and were thrilling and never dull
- Actually getting actors from the show to voice act their character in the game made it feel so much more engaging and authentic
- The length of each episode, hence the entirety of the game, was very much appriciated and made for an enjoyable experience.

Overall the game has it's ups and downs but still managed to give an authentic feel to the world of Ice and Fire.
Recommeded for fans of Telltale and/or Game of Thrones

reviewText: Game of Thrones - A Telltale Games Series really succeeds in telling a new story within already established narrative. I still had fun playing this game but the series feels unfinished, like there should be one more episode with a proper finale. But instead we're going to have to wait for the second season, I guess.\n\n7/10

reviewText:
I was forewarned by a friend not to expect much. That the story told in the game would not live up to the series.

I must say, after having played it, I must beg him to differ. The story is as close as it gets to a GRRM-level plot, without having the man directly involved himself in the writing.

There are surprises aplenty, and characterisations, that get you really involved.

Story-wise, my only complaint is that the Forrester family feels like a palette-swap of the Starks at times. They are still their own personalities, but you still have the southron widowed Lady who was married to a honorable, strong northern Lord, etc.

The graphics are admittedly bad, which at times can be distracting, but overall, a very enjoyable experience that I would recommend playing if you are a fan of the Song of Ice and Fire universe.

reviewText:
Important! Episode 1 for this game contains spoilers for up to the end of Season 3 of Game of Thrones.

This game starts with a really strong first episode. It really has me hooked and I can't wait to play the rest of the episodes!

It sucked me into the storylines and I really cared about the characters, and had to think through my decition trying to make it so it had the best outcome possible. The graphics are a hit and miss. Sometimes, the enviroment looks pretty and sometimes it looks blurry and low quality, it is an area where Telltale should really imrpove upon.

If you are a fan of Game Of Thrones, buy this game and enjoy it. If you are a fan of of Point and Click adventures but you haven't seen up to the season 3 of Game of Thrones, then watch the series and then buy the game. It's best to play when you know the world you are in.

reviewText:
Telltale truly outdid themselves with Game of Thrones. Never have I clenched my butt so much throughout an episodic story-driven game.

It helps (a lot) to be knowledgeable on the series/GoT universe, be it watching the TV show or reading the books; but you can still enjoy the game as its own story. The characters, the plot-twists, and the semi-illusion of control over the decisions one can make are all executed extremely well.

Would you like a book or a movie where the main character (or characters) are always suffering? I wouldn't. And although a game, the Telltale's Game of Thrones is doing just that.

reviewText:
Oh this game...how to describe it...

Well I guess I'll open saying that I am both a huge GoT fan, as well as a telltale games fan, and I feel that it is because of both of these facts that I was unable to enjoy the game to it's fullest. Allow me to explain, and fair warning, this review will contain major spoilers.

On the game of thrones side, the setting and timing was great. It takes part just after the red wedding, and puts you in the place of a family whos entire life was turned upside down from this. Stroke of genius. In one fell swoop we have our conflict, and fits damn well within lore. But from there we start to slip. we're introdced to the importance or ironwood, our main commodity. We're told how important it is, and because of it just how important our family is. Every character in the game treats us with some level of respect because of this (or at least will lend us an ear), but often in ways that make little sense. We encounter many characters from the books/show, but they feel weird, and often their power doesn't gel with their position. For example, john snow has seemingly way too much sway at the wall for the time period, or Ramsey just outright being untouchable (though this is as much a fault of the show as it is the game. Difference is here I have control)

And here is where we get to the telltale side. I understand with these games, to an extent you're always on rails, but it feels agregious here. Far too many times it doesn't matter what you do, the outcome will be the same. And the game isn't even subtle at times about this, with some very weird transitions that left me yelling angrily at the screen (My favourite one being I made specific safeguards to make sure this DIDN'T happen! Where the ♥♥♥♥ did they go?"). This unfortunately left me feeling cheated

reviewText:
Typical telltale and Game of thrones style (but with no sex), but does the almost constant downhill decline for the Forresters ruin the game? It feeds you just enough to make you think they have a chance at fighting back but by the end of each episode the threat just gets even greater than before.

Pros:
+When the graphics do work out they look great
+Mostly good story
+Cameos from TV show
+Play as multiple characters
+Lots of new choices from different characters
+Experience the story from multiple perspectives (get to see lots of people's motives and actions)
+Feels much more like a full world than other telltale games

Cons:
-Painting style art is really low res
-Buggy animations
-Bad lip syncing
-Story on a constant downer
-Cliffhangers everywhere
-Everything you care about dies
-False illusion on how much your choices actually matter

Final Verdict:
If you enjoy your hopes being brought up and then stomped on repeatedly be sure to buy this, and wait for season 2 for a hopefully les soul crushing story

7/10

reviewText: This game was hard to say if I liked it or if I didn't. So many choices felt like they didn't matter and the constant jumping between five different characters got a little frustrating when there was really only a few I wanted to follow. Was this a bad game? No it was not. Was this game frustrating in the end? Yes it was.\n\nIt seemed like almost every choice you made ended badly. Perhaps that is just the setting or maybe it's a reflection of bad storytelling and deliberate railroading disguised as giving you choices. It was filled with loose ends that never got tied up and I feel that it's meant to have a sequel. In the end I honestly cannot recommend it; there are better telltale games out there that you should be playing instead of this one. Here's hoping there is a sequel that is well...better.

reviewText:
Worth your time, honestly. I do recommend getting it on sale but that's true of any game. If you like Telltale's style definitely give this a try.


Overview:

Memorable characters - even the ones you spend very little time with matter to you enough that it will still make an impact to see them go.

Engaging gameplay - following TTG's format and mechanics but not necessarily repetitive, probably the one I've been more strongly forced to pay attention to if I didn't want to miss a command. Makes it much less dull than more forgiving Telltale games.

Good story - no dead moments, makes you want to push forward without needlessly excruciating cliffhangers (though I may be at an advantage for playing it all after the finale was out).

Amazing art style - fits incredibly well with the setting and honestly doesn't clip any more than any other Telltale game does, which is already not that much (for anyone who doesn't demand unattainable perfection).

Potential negative points:
There's a lot of character death, it's not a happy story by any means. Not sure what else you'd expect given the source material, though.

There's quite a lot of gore, might be off-putting even though the art style dulls it quite a bit (at least enough for me, and I'm squeamish).

Being into the series already means you know who's alive in canon so you know if they're gonna survive which might make a few decisions obvious or seemingly pointless, but it's not the majority and it doesn't ruin the game.

Some choices seem to be bugged.
Other notes:

I've played other Telltale games I was more invested in that ended up disappointing because they felt pointless in the end, like what you did either didn't matter or like what you thought was going to be important ended up not being brought up again, or a character getting completely ignored or have their development thrown out the window. I didn't get that feeling from this one, and it's refreshing.

Besides, you don't need to know a single thing about the universe to enjoy this and really get invested.
I've never seen a single episode of the show or read a single page of the books, I just enjoy Telltale's style of storytelling and gameplay enough to give all the more recent games a try.

Some negative reviews say the fact that this builds up to a season 2 is a bad thing, but seeing as we'll actually get one I don't see what the problem is. Better than unresolved eternal cliffhangers, and this one is actually a hopeful one, not just disorientingly open and vague.


TL:DR:

7.5/10

People need to stop demanding the impossible from choice-based games, this does everything it can to be able to fit in canon and still give you options.
It's honestly good, and it will make you angry but definitely in a way that will make you want more. If for nothing else, then for revenge.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

I'm of two minds about this adventure, the story starts strong, it's nicely integrated into the lore, you really feel the GoT vibe. Later on a couple of holes and absurd plot twists left me wondering which team of highly trained monkeys was in charge around episodes 3 to 5 (ep.5 is incredibly short by the way), but whatever, they must have been fired, because you need a decent finale to sell the next game, which we kinda have gotten.
Choices don't matter, but the feeling they do is nice 'till you know better, so stick to a single playthrough to be happier about it.
Overall it barely makes is to the recommended list, on a 66% off sale. 6,5 out of 10.

reviewText: Hamfisted twists, plotholes to accompany said forced twists, wasted potential, and an ultimate sequel hook baiting you in the face leads me to ultimately not recommend this series unless you enjoy being disappointed and aggravated by the end of the series.\n\nIt's become quite clear at this point that Telltale thinks the point and appeal of GoT is reducable to some cookie-cutter tragedy of the week formula. The tragedy would be worthwhile if it weren't par-for-the-course predictable AND awfully executed with plotholes galore. And if it isn't those glaring problems slapping you in the face, it's the wasted potential comes from your character investments (i.e. your 'choices') otherwise being meaningless.

reviewText: This is the only Telltale game I've played so far and I think the story is great. There was some unnecessary movement here and there. It could have been done for you since you could only move forward anyway. But that's just a detail.\n\nMost of the time it's about watching and reacting, listening and responding, about making fast decisions. And only players who are familiar with Game of Thrones TV series can feel excited about meeting some familiar faces or truly understand and accept the fact that you can't really fix things anyway. It's Game of Thrones after all.. Bloody and brutal!

reviewText: Telltale is one of my favorite developers, but comparing this title to The Wolf Among Us or Tales from the Borderlands is just unfair. This game came out riding in the TV show's wave of popularity. The choices you make don't matter all that much, the final outcomes end up being pretty similar to each other no matter your style of gameplay. Even the dialogue repeats itself most of the time and characters react to you much the same way no matter which side you pick.\n\nIt also felt recycled, even, like every character in the game has its counterpart in the main series, especially after the last episode. Seriously, you can swap the names of characters from this game with the book and you basically know how everything ends. It's not even a spoiler anymore. I think that they put all the effort they could to make you feel that this is a Game of Thrones game that it's too much like a Game of Thrones game, so it ends up being simply boring. Nonetheless, it's an okay title for fans of the genre and the series. Worth buying on sale. 4.5/10, I guess.

honestly this whole genre of movies masquerading as games has gotten so dull and game of thrones is just the reigning king of boring. i couldn't even finish the last episode. the gameplay is nonexistant: move around a bit, click here to pretend like you're actually doing something.

if you're looking for a fun time, skip it

reviewText:
Has its frustrating moments, some choices are narrow and irrelevant which result in reactions that you would not expect from the characters, and the graphics are blurry and skippy, with rather awkward transitions between scenes (although that may just be my GPU). I had to replay some sequences over a dozen times due to poor sensitivity with the controller based play where my cursor would overshoot the target at a slight push of the joystick.
However, it is a TellTale game, and so the story does have its merit, with some interesting twists and enough mystery to keep the player going. I feel like this game at points relies on what the TV show has begun to rely on, and that is the deaths of main characters as a plot device to keep the audience's attention. If interesting relationships and developments can't keep a game afloat then it will suffer to some degree.
It is a good game, I do look forward to the conclusion of the story, and I hope that the big reveal of the Northern storyline plays as big a part as a I hope it will.

7/10 Buy it on a sale.

reviewText:
They can't do it all the time. They just can't. They can't keep taking our beloved franchises, turn them into storytelling videogames and make those GOOD. Or can they?

Telltale's (TT) newest installment features the world of A Song of Ice and Fire, more commonly known as Game of Thrones, made popular by HBO's TV series. By now, you should be familiar by the way TT approaches gameplay, artstyle or how their games are split up into a number of Episodes being released in 1-2 month intervals. It should as no surprise that you will only have access to Episode 1 of this season, and by extension this review will focus on only that. This review will be spoiler-free for the actual games, but contain some spoilers from Seasons 1 through 3 for the TV series.

Game of Thrones - A TT Games Series puts focuses on the story of House Forrester, a lesser northern house that served the Starks for centuries and in return enjoyed their protection. When the War of the Five Kings broke out, however, the lands of Westeros became ravaged and the old order was more or less destroyed. The Northmen face their own problems as the Boltons seize power, backed by the Lannisters and King Joffrey.
What makes TT's game special is that it allows you to experience all those major events from a perspective you do not usually get much insight in. You, the protagonist(s), are not a global player in the overarching storyline. You have your own problems to deal with and are very much a subject to the whims of those more powerful than you. This alone makes playing the game worth it for hardcore fans as well, who might fear just replaying what they already know". While the game needs the main plot to establish its setting

reviewText:
A really great opening episode to this Telltale adaption of Game of Thrones. Very excited to see where it goes from hereon out.

Pros:
- The voice acting is real solid and has the show actors voicing their game counterparts.
- The story is massively engaging and takes place at the same time as the show/books.
- The characters are well-fleshed out and believable, with House Forrester fitting the game world perfectly.
- The graphic style is very refreshing and more realistic than the previous Telltale games, without going uncanny.
- A lot more attention to the sound and music than in earlier TT titles, sounds of pouring wine, cups being put down, birds and other little things make a huge difference in terms of immersing yourself in the game.

Cons:
- That nagging feeling that whether you choose A or B the outcome is still C, but at least the C will be a different color.
- Some weird character movement/pathing when you click on things to make cutscenes begin, will probably be fixed.
- The artwork, while absolutely gorgeous, relies a little too heavily on the new oil painting" style they've developed
date: making things look unfocused and washed out a bit too much at times.\n\nAll in all a really solid experience
recommended: best first episode of any Telltale game to date. Here's hoping it keeps as engaging and interesting throughout."

reviewText:
Worth your time, honestly. I do recommend getting it on sale but that's true of any game. If you like Telltale's style definitely give this a try.


Overview:

Memorable characters - even the ones you spend very little time with matter to you enough that it will still make an impact to see them go.

Engaging gameplay - following TTG's format and mechanics but not necessarily repetitive, probably the one I've been more strongly forced to pay attention to if I didn't want to miss a command. Makes it much less dull than more forgiving Telltale games.

Good story - no dead moments, makes you want to push forward without needlessly excruciating cliffhangers (though I may be at an advantage for playing it all after the finale was out).

Amazing art style - fits incredibly well with the setting and honestly doesn't clip any more than any other Telltale game does, which is already not that much (for anyone who doesn't demand unattainable perfection).

Potential negative points:
There's a lot of character death, it's not a happy story by any means. Not sure what else you'd expect given the source material, though.

There's quite a lot of gore, might be off-putting even though the art style dulls it quite a bit (at least enough for me, and I'm squeamish).

Being into the series already means you know who's alive in canon so you know if they're gonna survive which might make a few decisions obvious or seemingly pointless, but it's not the majority and it doesn't ruin the game.

Some choices seem to be bugged.
Other notes:

I've played other Telltale games I was more invested in that ended up disappointing because they felt pointless in the end, like what you did either didn't matter or like what you thought was going to be important ended up not being brought up again, or a character getting completely ignored or have their development thrown out the window. I didn't get that feeling from this one, and it's refreshing.

Besides, you don't need to know a single thing about the universe to enjoy this and really get invested.
I've never seen a single episode of the show or read a single page of the books, I just enjoy Telltale's style of storytelling and gameplay enough to give all the more recent games a try.

Some negative reviews say the fact that this builds up to a season 2 is a bad thing, but seeing as we'll actually get one I don't see what the problem is. Better than unresolved eternal cliffhangers, and this one is actually a hopeful one, not just disorientingly open and vague.


TL:DR:

7.5/10

People need to stop demanding the impossible from choice-based games, this does everything it can to be able to fit in canon and still give you options.
It's honestly good, and it will make you angry but definitely in a way that will make you want more. If for nothing else, then for revenge.

reviewText:
This one is a hard one to talk about. A review is a personal opinion so bare that in mind.

Game play wise this is standard tell tale, with similar point and click mechanicsa and conversation trees as Walking Dead or the Wolf Among Us. Similaly the graphics and presentation are standard tell tale as well, same pros same cons.

The main problem for me has been the story of the game. I have played through all of the game apart from the last chapter of the last episode, the reason why I gave up so close to the end was because of the story. Every desicion I have made has lead to a terrible consiquence, I chose to be honest a couple of times, I got slapped for it, I tried to be clever, I got slapped for it, I tried to be brave, I got slapped for it. Just when I thought I was making head way in helping house Forester, there was a twist that through me further into trouble. Now you may be reading this thinking, but of course it is like that, its Game of Thrones, not My Little Pony, I like the books, I liked the show, the difference is I am not making the desicions for the characters in the books, I am not dealing with misery upon misery upon misery, with no end in sight. The worst part is the Ending, which I looked up after I gave up the story.

Personally I would not recomend this game due to the simple fact that I feel cheated. This is not a story, this is a guilt trip  simulater, every single little desision you make, every word that leaves your mouth leads people to get offended or take advantage. If you want to play a Stark family simulater, then be my guest I will not be coming back for season 2 because, well they have a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ season 2. Tell a full story, like in the Walking Dead or Wolf Among Us.

Dissapointed Tell Tale, Dissapointed.

reviewText:
I loved the Walking Dead Telltale games and as a huge SOIAF fan I really expected to love this game as well. The first five parts were pretty good. It was a bit disappointing that your decisions don't actually effect anything (at least in the first episode, I never bothered replaying the others) but that's really true of any Telltale games (probably their biggest fault in general) and yet hasn't negatively effected my enjoyment of their other stories.

The second last episode ended with a tremendously difficult decision which seemed like it should dramatically effect the final chaper and left me feeling excited to see what they would do with it. Then after months of waiting for the final part I had sort of lost my immersion in the story and when I finally did get around to playing it, I found the ending chapter extrodinarily underwelming. The ending left me feeling bored, helpless, and just tired of being a loser. There were no characters which I really bonded with. It all felt like a lot of sacrifice and loss for nothing. I get that GRRM kills a lot of characters in his books and his characters suffer a lot but that is not the single element which makes his stories so compelling and yet it seems to be the only thing the show and this game took away from it. The story has to be gritty and real without simply being depressing.

I love games with a good story and I enjoy the interactive movie style of gameplay. I thoroughly enjoyed both Walking Dead games and would recommend them easily but, sorry Telltale, I wouldn't recommend this one.

reviewText:
I can't bear to give this game a thumbs-down, though actually it kinda does deserve one.

Harsh game, harsh story, just like the books.  In this respect, Telltale delivered a quite fine GoT atmosphere for players to enjoy(?) for a while, but honestly, it's so true: your decisions don't have any long-term relevance.  Don't wanna kill that guy?  Then don't...but OOPS well you get the blame and punishment anyway!  It got to the point where I realized that I might as well be as much of an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as the NPCs were being to me -- at least that way I'd get the satisfaction of flipping the bird/twisting the knife/spitting in their face before being forced to grovel by Lord Total Prick of House ShiteMeister.

So, if you like this sort of pain, do certainly buy and enjoy.  Otherwise, just stick with Tales from the Borderlands and feel actual happiness at the end of every episode.

The devs knew was popular so they make him take a completely inappropriate interest in one of the player character's just to pander to fans. Lena Headey was on point though.

reviewText:
I cannot review this game without talking about the story, so warning for those who have not played there are SPOILERS here.

With that out of the way, the game is set as a companion to the television show. Main characters from the show will apear and you can interact with them (but never play as them) and it even goes as far as to use the shows opening titles sequence. This means as such the game has spoilers from the television show in it, the game takes place through the events of series 4 of the show, so it is best to have watched series 4 before you play.

The game is seporated out into six episodes this time rather than the ususal five, which is fitting as it is a game of two halves. The first three episodes are done very well with lots of setup which leads to a great mid series finale at the end of the third episode.

The thing is thats the good parts over, from episode 4 onwards it starts to go down hill and doesn't recover. To be blunt the Forresters are the Starks. From episode 4 to the end you will watch as each Forrester is killed off one by one. The choices you make to try and save people don't matter as the bad guys will win. I realised this part way through episode 5 which made episode 6 a chore to play through. I will give them credit though, they do a good job of giving you hope that maybe you might actually succeed in something before undoing all your plans and again killing off characters.

The game has four playable characters and you switch between them as they are all in different locations, but come the end I only had one character left. The main plot point that is set up at the begining of episode 1 is meaningless and isn't resolved and has no impact on the story what so ever. You're supposed to find this 'North Grove' and you spend all five episodes searching for it and when you do find it the game ends.

This is a game where your choices are meaningless, the bad guys will ultimatly always win and deaths are just in there for shock value. This is Telltales worst output so far and I can't recommend it at all. There is a series 2 for whatever reason, everybody's dead so unless they wan't to start off with another new family there isn't much they can do.

reviewText: Telltale is one of my favorite developers, but comparing this title to The Wolf Among Us or Tales from the Borderlands is just unfair. This game came out riding in the TV show's wave of popularity. The choices you make don't matter all that much, the final outcomes end up being pretty similar to each other no matter your style of gameplay. Even the dialogue repeats itself most of the time and characters react to you much the same way no matter which side you pick.\n\nIt also felt recycled, even, like every character in the game has its counterpart in the main series, especially after the last episode. Seriously, you can swap the names of characters from this game with the book and you basically know how everything ends. It's not even a spoiler anymore. I think that they put all the effort they could to make you feel that this is a Game of Thrones game that it's too much like a Game of Thrones game, so it ends up being simply boring. Nonetheless, it's an okay title for fans of the genre and the series. Worth buying on sale. 4.5/10, I guess.

honestly this whole genre of movies masquerading as games has gotten so dull and game of thrones is just the reigning king of boring. i couldn't even finish the last episode. the gameplay is nonexistant: move around a bit, click here to pretend like you're actually doing something.

you play as several different characters but only 1 of them is a girl and she can possibly die if you choose it so. thanks telltale.

if you like the show, play it. the forresters are a cool idea and the game has some interesting world building. beware though certain characters do seem to act out of character (margaery knowing your whole family is literally dying but being more concerned with you not showing up at a party? i don't remember her being that horrible)

if you're looking for a fun time, skip it

reviewText: When every character you have to interact with in this game of clicks(plus cutscenes!)  is either outwardly detestable or pretending to be well-meaning, it saps any value to choice-making. Am I trying to suss out who I should trust or am I just a victim of attempting to trust any of these horrible people. It's one thing on the television show, but this is a game. I just feel angry after playing this game. Or rather, after watching this game, since a large portion of it is just watching things you have little control over. Telltale shakes their money maker once again.

reviewText: Your choices generally don't matter, the wait between episodes was ghastly (though their all out now), the quality from episode to episode is schizophrenic, and the ending is pure sequel bait. Off the top of my head I can think of really only two choices you can make that are of any real consequence and those are in the final two episodes. I can really only recommend this to people who are lore completionists or die-hard Telltale fans, but if you're on the fence about this game I suggest you give it a pass.\n\nAs a stray observation, the scenes with Tyrion made my stomach churn. The devs knew was popular so they make him take a completely inappropriate interest in one of the player character's just to pander to fans. Lena Headey was on point though.

reviewText: On the one hand, I was very emotionally invested in this game start to finish; not quite as tear-jerking as Telltale's The Walking Dead, but definitely close at times. Unfortunately the whole illusion of choice" thing that Telltale games do doesn't really work as well with a game about political intrigue as it does with something with an inhuman outside threat like zombies
date: and the emotion you'll most often be feeling is rage and frustration as things go from bad to worse to humiiliating time and again. There really isn't a great way to explain how truly meaningless all of your choices are in this game without going into spoiler territory... but basically you'll just find again and again and again that when you're given choices between who to pledge loyalty to
recommended: or whether to uphold commitments you've made

reviewText:
#NeverForget.. :'(




__________________________________________________________________


From ice, from ice, we Forresters born,
To ice we all return.
Father, brother, I've sworn, I've sworn,
To guard this rest you've earned.

May kings and queens melt down their crowns.
Up high on Aegon's hill.
In floods of gold, I pray they drown,
For all the blood they spilled.

Mance, sound the horn of winters past.
Call starving giants forth.
Urge cannibals to break their fast,
On wardens of the North.

Eastern mages empty the veins,
Of beasts across the sea.
Paint Slaver's Bay in crimson rains,
To bring Ethan back to me.

Snow grabbed me from my mother's grasp,
To claim me as his prize.
Ethan freed me from Ramsay's clasp.
The rival lords locked eyes.
The rival lords locked eyes!

Fight on, fight on, Ethan the Brave,
Old gods bear steel with you.
Our lord, my twin, a hero's grave.
So iron grows anew.
Still iron grows anew.

reviewText:
It started out strong, amidst the hype of the tv show, this game seemed to offer a cure for GoT withdrawal.

Alas, the story wasn't explained well enough in the end, the gameplay wasn't the best, and every couple of minutes you are faced with a loading screen.

You're left feeling as though none of your choices mattered except your last ones.

It can be resource taxing depending on your pc, and how much you run in the background. (I run a lot in the background)

---

All in all I'd say: Pick it up if it's on sale, but don't go in with high expectations

reviewText: I wish I could recommend this game. Telltale has done several other fantastic game adaptations, but the writing was stale in this one. Whenever I thought I was getting invested in the story, something cliche or completely expected from the Game of Thrones universe happened. I felt like the writers were trying so hard to be faithful to Game of Thrones that they weren't willing to deviate from the formula we've expected from the books/show: life is awful, people kill each other, politics is dangerous. If anything, the parts with Mira drew me in because her segments focused much more on navigating dialogue choices rather than quick-time events for action-heavy (but generally without character drama) sequences.\n\nThis wasn't a technically bad game, but it wasn't an interesting game.

reviewText:
After playing all 6 episodes, I'm disappointed. By the end of the final episode, I didn't really care what happened to House Forrester.

BackgroundYou play various characters of House Forrester, a House not really mentioned at all in the novels or the HBO series. They're Northerners, allied with the Starks, but with little power. The family is spread out across the world, so you get to see places you will recognise if you've followed the series at all - King's Landing, Meereen, etc. The timeline you play in is between the Red Wedding until slightly after the Purple Wedding.

Pros+ You get to meet familiar faces from the series - John Snow, Tyrion, Cersei, Daenarys, Ramsay
+ They got the real actors to voice their counterparts in the game
+ Interesting history behind House Forrester
+ Characters of House Forrester are pretty well designed and developed overall
+ Some nice plot twists, but nothing mind-blowing

Cons- Your choices don't really matter. Most deaths and events in the final episode are not preventable, no matter what you do in the first 5 episodes.
- The graphics aren't good, especially the backgrounds. Trees and ground textures look strange and not detailed.
- The opening theme song/animation, which was so-well done in the HBO series, looks weird and poorly rendered in the game.
- It's a shame you can't meet more characters from the TV series.
- Events in the novels/TV limit what the writers can really do for House Forrester. For example, options like trying to attack or offend Ramsay Snow will never turn out well because he's a main character, so you know there's no way to really do much against him.
- A few story points that are mentioned in the game, especially the North Grove, are never properly explained.

reviewText:
#NeverForget.. :'(




__________________________________________________________________


From ice, from ice, we Forresters born,
To ice we all return.
Father, brother, I've sworn, I've sworn,
To guard this rest you've earned.

May kings and queens melt down their crowns.
Up high on Aegon's hill.
In floods of gold, I pray they drown,
For all the blood they spilled.

Mance, sound the horn of winters past.
Call starving giants forth.
Urge cannibals to break their fast,
On wardens of the North.

Eastern mages empty the veins,
Of beasts across the sea.
Paint Slaver's Bay in crimson rains,
To bring Ethan back to me.

Snow grabbed me from my mother's grasp,
To claim me as his prize.
Ethan freed me from Ramsay's clasp.
The rival lords locked eyes.
The rival lords locked eyes!

Fight on, fight on, Ethan the Brave,
Old gods bear steel with you.
Our lord, my twin, a hero's grave.
So iron grows anew.
Still iron grows anew.

reviewText:
Honestly, don't buy it unless it's on sale for $5 and you're in need of a Game of Thrones fix. If you've played Walking Dead Season 1, then basically it's the same exact thing except with Game of Thrones as the setting, with the exact same choices as the rest of the Telltale games as of late. It makes you feel like the choices have a big deal but all they do is change some lines of dialog, BUT THE STORY NEVER CHANGES AT ALL DESPITE THEM TELLING YOU IT WILL.

BUT HEY, LET'S MAKE A GAME AND JUST COPY THE STARK FAMILY FOR THE MAIN CHARACTERS BUT LET'S CHANGE THEIR NAMES AND MAKE 90% OF THE THEM VAPID AND SHALLOW. By the time Episode 6 rolled in I just wanted all of them dead, especially the one that resides in King's Landing where they give you a few chances to live, and there wasn't a timer on the dialog choice so they wanted to guilt trip you, but screw it I wanted her dead not because it was honorable, it was because the writing was garbage for her and honestly she deserves to die for being so stupid. Same thing with notcatelyn stark, and really all of them that I didn't hesitate to not save them from dying. Trust me, you'll have sympathy for the notstarks at first, and by the end of it you'll turn into a psychopath that just wants everyone in this game to die in the most horrible way possible.

Also because the story is set right after the Red Wedding in Season 3 and plays out during Season 4, you already know what happens plot wise in the whole ASOIAF universe, and yes they do have you interact with major characters in the TV show so if you're caught up to date with GOT/ASOIAF books, YOU ALREADY KNOW WHAT HAPPENS TO THEM, like they tried to tempt me Episode 5 into trying to kill Ramsay Bolton and they shame you for not killing him when they had the chance, but SURPRISE, IT'S SEASON 6 ALREADY AND HE'S ALIVE ON THE SHOW SO IT'S OBVIOUS THAT YOU WON'T KILL HIM AND PROBABLY BAD THINGS WOULD HAPPEN IF YOU ATTEMPTED TO KILL HIM SO WHY BOTHER.

Basically if you want to play a good Telltale game go buy Sam & Max, or Back to the Future, or any of the games that still followed the traditional adventure model before they went to the current system in The Walking Dead because it's just god awful now. If you really want to play a Game of Thrones game, go buy Crusader Kings 2 and download the mod, it has an unforgiving learning curve and still not quite accurate but god it's better than this pile of garbage.

reviewText: As a reader of the series, I have to admit that this game is pretty reminiscent of the story. Telltale never fails to disappoint, at least disappoint me, but it can be a bit too straight forward sometimes. Though it must've been difficult to cram so much into a 6 part game, sometimes it feels rushed, other times slow. That has to be my only complaint though, for this is a really nice game. Decent graphics, great voicing, good story. It was even released on my birthday! But be a bit careful before buying it. The game takes place during the middle of the book Storm of Swords, so if you haven't read the two books before it, or caught up to (I think) season 3 of the show, you will probably be confused. I recommend buying it, but you should probably wait for it to go on sale, since it's quite pricey. That's what I did, and I got a good deal and had a good time.

reviewText:
Another month, another Telltale finale is upon us. This time it's Game of Thrones and we see whether Telltale learned a thing or two from their years of making these interactive games I hesitate to call adventure games but feel comfortable enough stating they have indeed carved their own niche at this point, niche even other developers have decided to dabble in.

While it is not necessary to be familiar with ASOIF as such, probably better known as Game of Thrones these days thanks to its namesake TV show,  it certainly helps and game references as well as heavily adheres to visual style of the ongoing series. Perhaps even a bit too much, in my opinion. So much so that House your characters belong to, House Forrester, at times feels like merely a stand-in for better known Starks and all the shenanigans that ensue can certainly be used to draw some clear parallels between the two. Yes, you read that correctly – characters. Taking up after their recent Borderlands game Telltale has opted to once again go for multiple-playable-characters-tied-together scenario, probably in the vein to emulate source material's multiple POVs structure as well. I have to admit I like the idea, but its execution simply wasn't that great because, for the most part, stories don't really tie together until the very end  and even then only for some while a good half still remains standalone without many ties to the rest.  Game is also perfectly content to re-tread a lot of the same ground, beat-by-beat, that was already covered in the books and, by proxy, the show itself. Yes, politicking in King's Landing, for example, is all nice and good but we've seen it all before and done better.

What I'm trying to say is game could've done its own thing, perhaps following in the footsteps of the Game of Thrones RPG, but it largely chooses not to in order to play on familiar imagery. It was entertaining to see how they played up signature shock factor when certain key characters keeled over, but I can't shake the feeling this was yet another game that suffered from lack of cohesive vision over what to do with it and some events that were built up as major never really amount to anything and end up simply left somewhere on they wayside forgotten because, in now standard formula approach, you dance to whatever tune Telltale ultimately decides they want to play.

I imagine this may come off as exceedingly negative opinion, but I assure you I was really torn on how to thumb the game in the end. It's not a bad game or anything, but following after Tales from the Borderlands it's clear Telltale's heart wasn't in this one and just comes off as a B-grade product in comparison. And I would consider myself a fan of the source material. Telltale simply needs to step up their game at this point or shake up the formula a bit because it's getting stale and this one had none of the personality or atmosphere to really sell it to me.

It's a Telltale game.

reviewText:
In really wanted to love this game, but it ended up just being disappointing. This is definitely my least favorite Telltale game. The main problem with it is that your choices change nothing. There's not even an illusion of choice. Your choices don't even change the dialogue most of the time. It feels very linear and on rails. Every choice felt like the wrong one because the game just thwarts your plans no matter what you do. I didn't feel like I was making any progress. There were so many plot holes it was ridiculous. The ending sucks no matter what you do. There were many choices where you can specifically set a course of action, but that choice gets ignored by the game anyway.

I had a lot of minor gripes with the game as well. There's basically no exploration or puzzles. Waiting an entire year for the whole game to come out really sucks. You completely forget everything so if you play it as it comes out it really hurts the experience. I'm not a fan of the blurry oil painting graphics. Some of the combat sequences were frustrating. There's no Steam cloud saves so I lost all my progress when my computer crashed. Playing so many different characters made it a lot harder to connect with any of them.

Spoilers: Immediately losing Asher or Rodrik as soon as Asher gets to Westeros and they meet up really annoyed me. The traitor reveal scene was really lame in my opinion. It was so predictable and uninspired that it fell completely flat. It didn't make much sense to me and I thought it was really out of character. Mira's entire storyline was basically pointless. I was waiting for Tom the coal boy to help me because he kept saying that there were people who would, but instead I just got executed. I was loyal to Margaery the whole time and she still didn't save me. They killed off so many characters by the end that it was worse than the Starks. The entire North Grove storyline came to nothing. They introduced new characters beyond the wall so late into the storyline that they were completely ineffective.

Season 2 was just announced. I really hope they do a better job. The writing needs to be a lot better.

reviewText:
If you don't like reading, here's a video review: http://youtu.be/4A4KnXrKkXE

Telltale's Game of Thrones is pretty much what you would expect from a Telltale Games title. It's another interactive narrative experience just like the Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us, but this time, it's centered around the Game of Thrones universe. For those watching the TV show, the game starts right at the end of season 3, at the red wedding. You know what I'm talking about.

That said, I really liked the first episode for Telltale Games Game of Thrones. It captured the essence of the show quite well in all aspects of the narrative, and even if you're not a big fan of video games in general, this is a must play for those who like the Game of Thrones books or TV Show. You play from the perspective of 3 different characters with very distinct roles. They all know each other, but they never actually meet, at least not in this episode. Like the TV Show, it's constantly jumping from character to character giving you these very different perspectives. From the mind games of King's Landing to the war games of the battlefront.

As I've mentioned before, in terms of gameplay, it happens pretty much as you'd expect. Lots of dialogue and different options which will cause a direct impact on the game. What certain characters think of you, whether they trust you or not, is all up to the way you choose to respond to them.
From time to time, there will also be some action sequences with quick time events which Telltale just doesn't seem to be able to let go. I'm really not a fan of these, I'd much rather be watching a cutscene than doing these quick time events. Pressing keys at the right time, is not what I'd call good gameplay mechanics, and most of them don't even matter, because even if you fail to press a key in the right time, it's barely going to change anything. I wish they'd just drop this feature entirely in the future, or replace with something that would actually be compelling to do, because every time I see these button prompts, I can feel my eyes suddenly rolling upwards, it's kind of a reflex of mine.
The soundtrack and voice acting are flawless, or close to that I would say. The actors of the show actually voice their own characters and they do a superb job of it.

Visually, the game is okay. It's not impressive, it's not crazy good looking, it's just okay. I can live with it, but some character models do bother me to an extent. Margery being the worst case, I don't think they were able to capture her face very well. There are good models though, if we look at Cersei and Tyrion, they look spot on, but from time to time, some wierd faces will appear. Also, why the hell did they try to recreate the intro from the TV Show? It's by far the worst looking part of the game. Look at those textures, that is horrible, and was completely unnecessary. This doesn't add anything to the game at all, so it's very weird that they decided to include it.

But these complaints feel very minor when compared to the good things that the game has in general.
There is although something I noticed after playing through the game twice. The game is fine for a single playthrough but when I played the game a second time to see the actual impact of your choices in the story, I was actually very disapointed. You can't change anything major. Characters will talk to you differently, they'll seem to trust you more or less, but there aren't any significant changes in their behavior or any major events. You can't save any character from dying, if they die in one playthrough they'll die in any other, they'll go to the same places, they'll interact with the same people at the end. This was kind of a bummer, but it was something that I only discovered after playing the game twice. I'll tell you this, Telltale is really good at creating the illusion that your choices matter in this episode, but at the end of the day, they really don't change a thing. That's not to say that your actions won't have a more meaningful impact in future episodes, but right now we can't say for sure.

Overall, very positive feelings about this game. Telltale and Game of Thrones go very well together, and I can't wait for the next episode, because as usual, this one ends on kind of a clifhanger, but that much was expected I guess.

reviewText:
Game of Thrones is a point+click game which is incredibly similar to The Walking Dead series. If you love TWD, you'll love this. Unlike TWD, however, the lore is much deeper, and so you might be confused if you don't understand or are not familiar with the Game of Thrones TV shows. Much easier for the shows' fans to get into the game.

And no, despite this game seemingly is suitable for casuals, it is NOT family games. There are explicit gore and violence, so I don't recommend you to play this with your kids.

The game sets itself in a medieval era of (fantasy) United Kingdom, or so it looks to me like so. At any rate, there's no UFO, so yeah, but there are Dragons and other magical creatures. There are factions, there is King and Queen, and of course bloody conflicts and wars between landlords. You'll be given chances to control at least four major characters and you'll be rotating around them, one of a time. Sometimes it is annoying to have the game switches the character your control, simply because you want more story revealed from that character.

And therein lies the beauty of this game, it is the story. It is capable to disorient you and oftentimes makes you choose an option that you wouldn't have done normally. When I think 'ok gotta be cruel u die sux ♥♥♥' then the game manages to exploit my weak side and so I relent. Sometimes I immediately regret the option I just chose, not so wise, eh?

The decision you make will alter the reactions of NPCs, but sadly the story will most likely end up the same. This is what I criticize, as I would expect this to have different branches of stories and multiple endings. Just an illusion, I guess.

At the moment there are only four episodes out of promised six, so I can't give final judgement. But so far, it is able to make me attached to the characters I play and I love the story it narrates. Can't wait for more chapters.

On a technical side, performance wise, the game runs silky smooth in my toaster (i7 3517u, 6 GB RAM, 635m GT), so no complaints from me. It is designed with console-PC hybrid in mind, so either using controller or KB/M don't yield so much discrepancy in experience. The game is able to detect my Dinput mode Logitech controller as well, as to be expected from Telltale as their TWD games also can.

Lastly, as for the recommendation, despite its flaw in to be expected multiple branches of the stories, I'd still give this a solid 9/10. Really enjoying playing this game.

reviewText:
+++ GREAT STORY +++ GREAT ART DESIGN +++ GORE +++ LIFE & DEATH DECISIONS +++ WITHOUT HAPPY END
I like the game and I recommend it not only to fans of the series or fans of Telltale games in general.

You don't need to be a Game of Thrones fan, you do not even need to have ever heard about the books or the series -- like I did before -- to immersive in the atmosphere, to understand the story, to actually like the game. I love the art style, I like the twisted story and the very interesting characters. It has great voice acting and enough gore effects to keep the family happy. I liked the controls and the speed of the game. Not too hasty, not too slow. The majority of the story lines are constantly interesting and well-written with plenty of (in terms of story unpleasant) surprises.

Overall it has been a great Telltale experience...

... until the end, until the last couple of minutes where the game stops abruptly, the moment all the decisions you were taken seem not have had any impact on the outcome of the game at all, when the twist, the storyline fail to round up properly. Leaving you back hungry, confused and wondering why the heck are they end the game this way? Might be a typical Game of Thrones twist. I don't know... as I said I am not a connaisseur of Games of Thrones, but I am not happy with the form of the happy end

It is a great story that comes along in a great art style and sufficiant interaction. However it might leave you behind with surprise, wondering why the knot in the twist just does not unleash...

RATING: 7/10
(-1 especially for the last episode and the ending)

reviewText:
The Telltale game, Game of Thrones, is as brutal as the books/TV series. Even from the start, I didn't had a problem to immerse myself within the game, think like the characters would do, and suffered the consequences that wouldn't dishonor G.R.R.M's name. Surely, each time he is involved, I lose a part of my soul.
I recommend the game to GoT fans and RPG fans alike.

Game of Thrones'un Telltale tarafından çıkarılmış oyun versiyonu kesinlikle Kitapları veya Dizisi kadar vahşi. Başlangıçtan itibaren oyunun sunduğu dünyanın içine girmekte ve karakterlerin düşüneceği şekilde düşünmekte zorlanmadım, bununla beraber G.R.R.M'in adını lekelemeyecek sonuçlara katlanmak zorunda bırakıldım. Zaten kendisinin dahil olduğu herşeyde, ruhumdan bir parça daha eksiliyor. Oyunu GoT hayranlarına ve RYO oyuncularına tavsiye etmekten çekinmiyorum.

reviewText:
I enjoyed the story and the inlusion of characters from the T.V. show.

I was very disapointed with the elusion of choices.
I played point 6 several times just to see if I could change the outcome for the begining of the next episode.  I was more than a little disapointed to discover that no matter what I chose, it did not change any of the responses from the characters or the final outcome.  I even whent to the extreme of letting each prompt expire during the entire chapter.  Not one character had a different response and the outcome remaind the same!  If chapter 6 is any indication of the level of detail Telltale Games has put into this game, then I just may have paid $30 for a slow moving movie with bad graphics! grrr

I also would like to mention that I was VERY surprised to discover that I paid $30 for only 1 episode!.  Nowhere in the About this Game" is it mentioned that I would be subsidizing the development of this game by paying for all 6 episodes but only getting episode 1.  Furthermore
date: Steam has not provided any readily available information on when the remaining 5 episodes are to be released!  If you look on the SONY Playsation Store
recommended: this game is listed as episode 1 only for sale at the same price or less than this package deal from Steam.  Perhaps SONY agrees with me that selling a product before it is released
hoursPlayed: with no indication to the public that this is taking place
voteText:
is not good business pratice. hmmm

Rant over! ;)

With all the above said and considering I have already paid.  I am actualy looking forward to the release of the remaining episodes.  Like I said above

reviewText: Game of Thrones is abitious, just like the show, with twist's and turn's depending on the choices you make, it keep's you guessing and wanting more like any good episodic game should. The main concern so far is that the game will be too surprise filled that it becomes an M. Night Shamalan movie and after the first few you'll be sick of it. If you guys at Telltale have this one played out with twist's and turn's don't make them too drastic. Anyway right now I love it and I am enjoying the cast being there and the fact that they are pretty much keeping with the feel and tone of Game of Thrones IMO. I need to mention that the oil painting style of the game is really cool. I just hope that it will get better, which most telltale games do, but as the T.V. show does, we may not get any real closure until the final episode, and even then it will be a miracle if it wraps everything up.  If you want to know about gameplay, they were good with doing the telltale thing in games, that being a mix of point and click elements, dialouge choices, desicion making on a butt hole clenching level, and quick time events. So basically I think the game will be good, a little hesitant, but I have hopes. Most telltale games usually get better with each new episode such as The Wolf Among Us where there was no real closure in the first episode, but in the end got better and better. Until then I think that everything was amazing for the first episode of six, in numbers i'd say it's a 9/10. In short short words, good, but you may want to hold off if these type's of games do not intrest you, or if you don't follow the show, but if you are one or both i'd say get it.

reviewText: If you enjoy the show, then I'm quite sure you will enjoy the game. If you are NOT familiar with the gameplay from the games from Telltale- it simply plays like an interactive movie. Filled with choices on what to say or do. There are also some quick time events here and there. But mostly, there's lots of talking. Just like there is in the show though, so I don't think that's a bad thing for fans of the series. The story is awesome. You'll meet and interact with few characters from the tv series as well some generic ones. The game has few cons though... The graphics aren't too realistic in my opinion. Most of games from Telltale have comic-like graphics, and in GoT it seems like they've struggled to make it look real"
date: and not really succeeding at it... It also would be great if the choices you make had a bigger impact on the story. And I should also mention that I don't think you can really get into the game if you didn't see the tv series. You'd just end up really confused on what's going on. But all things considered I think buying this game is a money well spent."

reviewText:
Alert : if you are not familiar with the series or the books, don't even consider buying this game as you will miss 90% of its interest. If you are farmiliar with it tho, then I have one question for you : WHAT THE HELL ARE YOU WAITING FOR ???!

The story is simply great, the choices you have to make are really hard and I think it's the first time I'm saying that about a telltale game, usually the choices are interesting and define who you are and who you want to be, and sure there are some tougher choices from time to time in the other games but in this one, everytime I have to chose it really does hurt my brain.

The characters really managed to make me feel emotions throughout the first episode and I believe they will continue to do so in the future.

The universe is really well reproduced, graphics look as good as you can expect. Don't judge them from the pictures. Once everything is animated, it really does click for me.

Overall, this first episode was great, I'd say it was my favorite episode in a telltale game so far, and now that most of the pieces seem to be set, I can't wait for those to come !

reviewText:
Apparently Cersei has a point: When you play the game of thrones you win or you die. There is no middle ground.

Keep that in mind when you play this game.

Unfortunetly, you're not playing for the throne. You're trying to keep your house from ruin and most of all, that somebody still has a pulse when the dust has settled. Hells bells, thats hard enough. Your snap decision a second ago just got somebody killed. That clever retort you just gave to a minor insult? Stupid and costly. I am slowly learning the price of loyalty. The price you pay for never bending a knee. And happily, I am learning how to scheme. This will come in handy in my next work review. ;)

The Forresters are front and center in this story. So the game of thrones are not yours to play, but I don't mind. The story is good enough to get me invested in the characters, even though their fate do resemble to the original cast a tad to much. And at one point in chapter 2 i tought:

Zevran! My old mate! How have you been? I haven't seen you since I last was in Ferelden." - Except this elf .. I mean assassin
recommended: you'll see what I mean.\n\nSo some characters don't feel very original. Nor the plot. But then again
hoursPlayed: you are in Westeros. And that I do like.\n\nAt times the handeling was a bit clumsy
voteText: but I have a feeling I should have been playing with pad and not mouse+keyboard.\n\nI could only change the settings after I started the story. A bit silly
helpfulPercent: but not a dealbreaker.\n\nI only had trouble at one time

But i think that might have something to do with me having two monitors. I adapted and overcame.\n\nIn sum: You're not playing the characters we know and love/hate. It's a story that focus on one family's plight. It does give you an advantage knowing the lore and having seen the series or read the books. We've only gotten to chapter 2
votesTotal: so expect to suffer untill you finally can get your revenge. And if I'm not wrong
votesFunny:
Martin will make that journey grueling.

But 7 hells ... I will get my revenge.
