reviewText:
First and foremost - this game is for prior fans of Game of Thrones; it is NOT a game for people looking to get into the franchise. If you haven't read up to A Clash of Kings  or watched up to Season 4 of the show (by which I mean you've finished them both), you're going to either be completely lost or you're going to have a lot spoiled for you. This game doesn't waste any time with explanations about anything fans of the series don't already know. It's not just the fact that you won't get the most out of this game if you aren't already a fan of The Game of Thrones franchise - it's that you'll be totally lost and confused within literal seconds of starting Episode 1.

That being said, if you're even a little bit of a Game of Thrones fan, this game is a must-play. You're put right in the middle of Westeros and all its countless problems, and, while all the characters you play as are exclusive to the game, you'll find yourself running into familiar faces all too often. The characters and the chapters are all very balanced; I often found myself put in the shoes of the exact character I was hoping to see next. Telltale's specialty of forcing players to make impossibly difficult decisions in a matter of seconds fits perfectly into the world of Game of Thrones, and there's no lack of the heart-stopping moments and jaw-dropping twists that fans of GoT and Telltale alike have come to love and hate so much. Not to mention the game's art style, which is just breathtaking; Telltale really has a knack for matching gorgeous and unique graphics to their perfect stories. The Walking Dead looked like a comic book come to life; Game of Thrones looks like an oil painting.

I have countless praises for this game and only three complaints as follows:
1) As of Episode 2, Daenerys has yet to make an appearance.
2) I didn't go to sleep until 3 AM the day I started the game because I literally wasn't able to stop playing it.
3) Episodes 3-5 aren't out yet.

Seriously, if you're a Game of Thrones fan, buy the game. It's worth it...and it'll definitely satisfy any GoT cravings you've had since finishing Book 5/Season 4.

reviewText:
It's a story driven experiance in the world of Game of Thrones. The game starts at the Red Wedding and continues onward from there. You play 3 characters, each are not important in the show. Your focus is to save House Forrester from ruin and destruction by the Boltons and Whitehills but your army has been dwindled to nothing because of the red wedding. You now need to save your house by any means possible before your house is lost. Do you have what it takes?



side-note
Like all telltale games, you are only given 1 episode every couple of months. If you are patient enough to wait that long to continue the story then go ahead and get it right now. But, if your not then don't buy this game right now. Wait till all the episodes are out, then buy it. All the episode should be out by, december 2015, roughly...give'er take.

reviewText:
When a great developer meets an epic universe, they create something incredible.

You need to know the universe of A Song of Ice and Fire to really enjoy this game, but when you do, you will probably love it. I know I did.

It's the typical Telltale game, choices seem to matter, the main characters are well written and believable. Localisation is superp, although the subtitles aren't the exact words at times. When it comes to gameplay, you have the typical quick-time-events and the choices (usually four), but Telltale games have never been about the gameplay. The style is great and fits the universe well. It captures the scenery (cold, simple North versus the extravagant King's Landing). Graphically you can't expect anything special. Some textures are not exactly high resolution and the AA is badly done.

A slight warning: Just like the books and the series, the game can be quite cruel and depressing.

I would recommend this to anyone who likes the books or series and wants to experience even more of A Song of Ice and Fire.

reviewText:
Game of Thrones by TellTale is interactive novel that starts off in one of the most memorable moments of GoT called the Red Wedding. If you haven't watched season 3 of the show or read the third book called Storm of Swords I would highly suggest you don't read this review or play this game. With that out of the way, we start off as a lowly squire for House Forrester named Gared Tuttle. He is out fetching wine for the soldiers in celebration of The North's plan to take Casterly Rock from the Lannisters. Things do not stay cheerful for long as Fray soldiers cut down the army of The North in a vicious sneak attack and your lord is slain before your eyes. In his final words he gives Gared a sword and asks him to return it to its rightful place in the Forrester keep called Ironwrath. He also mysteriously asks of him to tell his uncle “The North Grove must not be lost” which will kick start the main goal of that character. That is a lot of names to take in, which is why those with new to GoT will likely be very lost throughout since they are entering the world near the half way mark of the overall narrative.

One of the first things you'll notice is that the graphics now have this painting like look to them instead of the comic book style of Telltales last two games. It looks alright, not really anything remotely cool looking here but it does the job. The reason I mention the graphics so early on is that you will do a lot of sitting back and just watching in this title. Even compared to Telltales last two games, you can count on a single hand just how many times you will have control of your character and there are no puzzles either which is why I called this an interactive novel in the first sentence. That may be a bad thing to some but in my eyes those were the worst parts of Telltale's games and I'm glad I no longer have to move an extremely slow character around tiny closed off environments all that often. It makes the story move along with far better flow and is much easier to get invested in. Considering you will be controlling four characters in very different situations the better pacing benefits this title a lot. Like other Telltale games they will occasionally throw in a QTE to make sure you are paying attention.

The characters you play as will be the previously mentioned squire Gared, Ethan Forrester who is the new young lord after his father’s demise, Asher the black sheep of the Forrester family and Mira Forrester who resides in King's Landing as a handmaiden for the soon to be queen Margery Tyrell. All characters want what is best for House Forrester which makes switching around to another characters perspective feel natural since they are all fighting for the same thing, though in different ways. Their House's situation is extremely dire from the get go and Telltale really captured the dark feel of the GoT universe. You never feel safe and being a small barely known House that fought on the defeated side of the war you will constantly get harassed. Most of the time the wiser choice is to just accept it and stay silent but the humiliation you go through is just so much that more likely than not you will not be able to just put up with it even if you know it can cost you everything. Not that you have much left as whenever you think things are bad they somehow get much worse. From start to finish it feels like you are drowning and there is very little hope to be found anywhere.

It is a very dark game but unlike the show or books this has zero humor in it. That ties in with the biggest flaw in this game which are the choices you make. Telltale has always offered the illusion of choice but in this title there is no illusion. Your choices are meaningless and are foiled by the dumbest reasons just to keep the story the way they are trying to tell it. For instance in one scene you are going to get murdered by a Lannister guard but a small boy defends you and is being drowned for it. You have the choice to kill the guard or run away. If you run away you later meet the boy again who is now angry with you for leaving him to his fate and said he found a nearby rock while being drowned to kill the guard with. There is just no believable way such a small skinny lad could have pulled that off against a rather high ranking guard while being drowned in the position he was. It just feels like cheap and lazy story writing to pin that murder on you either way that you choose to handle things. That insultingly improbable way of negating your choices carries on toward the whole game and some are far more unbelievable than what I choose as an example.

With the lack of humor and the already dire situation with convenient plot armor keeping you from doing anything about it, it feels like the game is screwing the player instead of a dark, dangerous world where your plans don't always work out. It's a shame too as there are quite a few important characters of the GoT universe like Ramsay Bolton, Cerci Lannister and Jon Snow all with their original actors from the show. It would have been awesome to see if you could outwit the more dangerous of characters by using what we know from the show but instead we get the choice of picking the bad choice and getting shafted by the character for it or picking the sensible choice and getting shafted by the game itself for it. If Telltale were spread thin due to all of the games they are working on I feel it would have been far better to have a few actual choices rather than a ton of poorly veiled meaningless ones. From all this criticism you may be guessing that the story is garbage but the sad part is that it is not. It is a rather interesting tale with that spans from Westeros to quite a bit of Essos. You can't help but root for the Forresters and hope they get back on their feet.

They did an excellent job with getting you to despise the villains even if they are the typical absurdly evil type. All the new characters are pretty interesting, well voiced and quite likable. None feel like they are out of place in the GoT universe and are just as likely to die as anyone else. Well other than the show's cameo characters featured here who are too important to the plot of the show to kill off in a video game. Strangely enough for the GoT universe there is no nudity anywhere in this game, though I guess in the situations are characters are in they don't feel like baby making. All in all this is a game that will only appeal to fans of the Game of Thrones looking to see their favorite characters and see some famous locations like Castle Black, King's Landing and Mareen. There is a good story here but the pretentiousness of the frequent, useless choices did negatively impact the narrative. And the ending is a very unsatisfying set up for another season that had no closure at all. This is a title you can safely skip even if you are a fan of the source material. It's not a bad game but it does feel like a rushed plothole filled mess that only the biggest of fans that can't get enough of Game of Thrones will likely enjoy.

reviewText:
An interesting take on the Game of Thrones world.
You play as members of House Forrester, who are bannermen to House Stark, and the game starts just before the red wedding. Several members of the cast of the TV show lend their voices to their characters in the game, which gives a certain amount of credibility and believability.

Your choices whilst playing the game do affect somethings, but like all Telltale games there are times when choice is just an illusion and what's going to happen will happen no matter what you do. The game follows the general feel and atmosphere of the TV show, except it sometimes takes it even a step further when it comes to killing off characters. This can be hard to accept with your choices not always mattering, and you can feel you're just along for the ride and there's nothing you could of done to save characters you've grown attached to.

Despite this, it's nice to delve back into Game of Thrones while the TV show is on break, and Telltale always do a good job of creating engaging stories and characters. There's a good balance to the game, with times when you're in a political situation trying to make shrewd, difficult decisions, and other times when the swords are swinging and you have to press action button after action button.

With all episodes of season one now released, I would recommend picking it up when it's next on sale, and if you like Game of Thrones and Telltale games in general.

reviewText:
Game of Thrones is a game that had so much potential, yet somewhat failed to live up to expectations. Now don't get me wrong, the game is good. But choices mean little to nothing and not much is resolved in the finale. Mainly they used the popularity of the game as an excuse to not finish the story and instead announcing Season 2, which hopefully will fill the numorous plot holes that was left behind. But it still has the Telltale charm...you give a crap about the characters. The illusion of choice is just that-an illusion-but it is still fun nonetheless.

Pros:
-Characters/Character Arcs
-It genuinely hurts to be a jerk
-Choices can be extremely difficult, making them realistic
-Intriguing plot line
-Manages to maintain flow throughout multiple character switches
-Telltale still goes for the feels
-Game. Of. Thrones.

Cons:
-Episode 6
-Little choices matter
-Graphically unsound

Final Score: 7/10 - Good

reviewText:
It was hard waiting for all the episodes to come out and binge-play this, but this was totally worth it!

It lasts about 10 hours (about an actual GoT season) and it's incredibly well written, so it's the perfect thing to break the waiting to GoT Season 6.

It's the classic winning Telltale formula, with some annoying quick time events here and there (but it works much better than the other TT games in the fight scenes, especially in Ep5 and Ep6 in my opinion.)

I initially read there were some cameos from the TV shows (like in TWD season 1) but the original charachters from the show are actually more than a cameo since they play a crucial role in every chapter.

It takes place right after the tv show S03E10 (AVOID THIS GAME UNTILE YOU HAVEN'T SEEN THE SHOW AT LEAST TO THAT POINT).

Lacks boobs (as expected) but if you love the tv show, you must get this game asap.
